report_title: Bridge and Elevated Highway Construction Industry Report
executive_summary: Bridge and elevated highway contractors have faced modest declines over the current period. As local and state government investment has fallen recently, contractors have had fewer opportunities, pressuring profit. COVID-19 had a hand in putting construction behind schedule, as the global emergency forced the government to redirect funds away from bridge and elevated highway construction, especially considering that stay-at-home orders severely limited travel. Overall, revenue has been falling at a CAGR of 0.3% over the past five years to total an estimated $15.7 in 2024, despite an increase of 2.6% in 2024 alone.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: US Infrastructure is Slowly Falling Apart
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Since the advent of the interstate highway system in the 1950s and the wide acceptance of automobiles, the United States government has been responsible for maintaining safe roads, including elevated highways and bridges. According to the ASCE, constant battles for limited government funding have led to many bridges and elevated highways aging poorly with minimal attention, creating a backlog of $125.0 billion in repairs. According to the ACE, bridge spending must increase by 58.0% to address this considerable backlog.

Also, 43.0% of US roads are in poor or mediocre conditions and general US infrastructure was given a grade of C- in 2021 (ASCE produces a report every four years). This is putting an obvious strain on the government, meaning that investment in bridges and elevated highways has been necessary purely for safety, which has boded well for contractors late. The Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act (IIJA), which began federal funding in 2022, has offset some COVID-19-induced declines.

Local and state government investment returning to growth will provide opportunities for private contractors. This will continue to be the government's preferred method of accomplishing its infrastructure goals, as it provides the benefit of increasing business activity. Easing inflation and stronger economic prospects as interest rates fall will benefit contractors.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Necessity Will Keep Bridge and Elevated Highway Construction Moving
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As local and state government investment resumes growth, funding for elevated highways and bridges will be necessary as many bridges are in poor condition, putting citizens at risk. The ASCE considers 7.5% of bridges to be in poor condition and the Federal Highway Administration states that nearly a quarter of bridges are deficient and require replacement or rehabilitation. Also, according to the ASCE, nearly 231,000 bridges throughout the US require maintenance and repair.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: The Government to Continue Preferring Public-Private Partnerships
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The government benefits from increased business activity, keeping the economy healthy and increasing tax revenue. Public-private partnerships have long been the preferred method of completing infrastructure projects, as they inject cash into the private sector while improving public utilities. The vast number of projects available will lead to more contractors beginning to operate. The largest contractors will benefit the most moving forward, as they will be able to provide lower rates and take on many projects.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Economic Prospects Improving to Bolster Growth
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Inflationary pressures easing and interest rates falling will prop up consumer and business spending. While interest rate levels will remain high early, the Federal Reserve planning three rate cuts in 2024 will contribute to economic recovery. Better economic conditions will lead to greater tax revenue and increased infrastructure funding. As the condition of bridges and elevated highways continues to deteriorate, spending on them will be necessary for local and state governments.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Climate Change is Increasing the Threat to Existing Bridges and Elevated Highways
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As the condition of bridges and elevated highways across the country is far from ideal, they are at risk of destruction from natural disasters. As climate change continues to bring about unprecedented conditions, there will be an increase in natural disasters. As repairs lag, disasters, including earthquakes, hurricanes and tornadoes, could damage bridges and elevated highways beyond repair, creating the need to build replacements and multiplying the cost to the government.

industry_definition: This industry comprises companies that primarily engage in the construction of bridges and elevated highways. These types of projects include new work, reconstruction and repairs. This industry does not include road and highway construction activity.
key_trends: Competition for government contracts rides on price. The government always gives contracts to the lowest bidder, inducing price-based competition among contractors.
There are plenty of projects to go around. With the government increasing its focus on infrastructure and the backlog of projects piling up, the number of contractors has increased.
Contractors have endured modest declines - The outbreak of COVID-19 redirected construction funds to pandemic relief programs. - Federal funding for infrastructure ramping up offset some declines.

Contractors will grow as investment in infrastructure grows in importance - Aging bridges and elevated highways are strained due to a growing population and increasing natural disasters, limiting the government's ability to put off projects.
Companies are spread out across the country - Concentration is low as local governments seek companies that specialize in specific areas, as they can provide the most efficient service.
Sustainability is key to future success - As the world increases its focus on combating climate change, sustainable construction practices will be essential to success moving forward.

Government investment at the federal, state and local levels drives success - The government is the source of most projects, meaning the funding available for bridge and elevated highway construction comprises nearly all revenue.

Government regulation stipulates bridge and elevated highway safety standards - Especially as US infrastructure is aging, maintenance and new construction must be up to par to ensure safe travel for years to come.

Profit is held low by government funding - Limited funding for infrastructure leads the government to choose the least expensive option, keeping profit steady and relatively low. - Profit has dipped amid lower construction spending.

Wages are on the rise - With the increasing complexity of design and the high level of expertise required to work on these projects, workers are commanding better compensation. - Also, labor shortages have forced contractors to hike wages.

market_segmentation.segment: The State and Local Public Sector Remains the Top Market
market_segmentation.segment_description: State and local governments are the main market for contractors, as they are responsible for maintaining the bridges and elevated highways within their jurisdictions. The outbreak of COVID-19 cut into funding for infrastructure like highways and bridges following the implementation of various pandemic relief-focused programs, resulting in a growing backlog of projects. These projects can only be put off for so long before irreparable damage occurs and replacements are required, meaning spending on bridges and elevated highways will be a necessity moving forward.

The Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act has begun providing federal funding for repair and rebuilding of roads and bridges in 2022 and will continue through 2026, with the act providing a total of $110.0 billion. The federal government focuses this investment on the most traveled areas, almost exclusively along the interstate highway system it is responsible for, helping the country address the most pertinent structural issues first. The local and state public sector dwarfs the federal public sector since they are responsible for fewer bridges and elevated highways.

Private sector bridge and elevated highway construction are largely focused on small-scale residential and industrial developments, as public roads are comprehensive. Public-private partnerships don't fall under this market segment as the government contracts that work. This sector grew in importance when government spending was on the decline due to the pandemic-related disruptions, providing opportunities to replace the lack of government projects.

products_and_services.product_description: New Bridge and Highway Construction Remains Low on the Government's List of Priorities
The necessity for alterations and additions rises with growing urban populations and maintenance and repairs can only be pushed off for so long.
Essential maintenance and repair work necessary due to aging infrastructure.

tier_1_suppliers: Construction & Mining Equipment Wholesaling in the US
Surveying & Mapping Services in the US
Stone, Concrete & Clay Wholesaling in the US
tier_1_buyers: Agriculture, Forestry, Fishing and Hunting in the US
tier_2_buyers: Iron & Steel Manufacturing in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Local and state governments are responsible for maintaining elevated highways and bridges within their jurisdictions.
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Increased general investment indicates that more is being put toward these projects, as there is a constant and dire need for improvements. Local and state governments are the largest market that bridge and elevated construction contractors serve so their investment is crucial.

business_locations.location: The Largest Population Segment in the Southeast Necessitates Improvements
business_locations.location_description: The Southeast is home to the greatest percentage of the population of any region in the country. Thanks to many people, traffic becomes congested in the Southeast, so additions and alterations are necessary to help the free flow of travel. Safety concerns carry increased importance because of the substantial use of bridges and elevated highways in the region.

The West has grown in population over the years, with sunny California remaining a major draw to citizens. Cities in California and the rest of the West are heavily reliant on cars, with highways constantly getting expanded to include more lanes. While infrastructure in this region is mostly newer than its eastern counterparts, heavy use still necessitates maintenance, driving bridge and elevated highway contractors to the region.

business_locations.location: Cities in the Mid-Atlantic House Some of the Oldest Bridges
business_locations.location_description: Major cities including New York rely on bridges that are well over 100 years old and in constant need of maintenance. With cities in this area being so old, roads tend to be narrow, limiting the ability to expand elevated highways and bridges and hindering some growth for contractors.

regulations_points.regulation_title: THE GOVERNMENT STIPULATES BRIDGE AND ELEVATED HIGHWAY CODES
regulations_points.regulation_description: The American Association of State Highway and Transportation Officials (AASHTO) sets the standards which must be met when constructing a bridge or elevated highway. These standards exist to ensure safety and durability for the years to come. These codes pertain to pavement design, ride quality and roughness, noise emission, load and resistance factor design and more.

regulations_points.regulation_title: SAFE WORKING CONDITIONS ARE REQUIRED BY LAW
regulations_points.regulation_description: The Department of Labor's Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) oversees health and safety regulations on construction projects. Regulations include ensuring safety from traffic while working through barricades and flagging in addition to freedom from other hazards. Regulations also include that equipment like scaffolding and ventilation is required when there is a threat of falling materials or toxic inhalants.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The American Association of State Highway and Transportation Officials (AASHTO) sets guidelines to ensure the safety of elevated highways and bridges. The design involved in the projects taken on by contractors is complex, so legal compliance is required.

Start-up costs are relatively high, as considerable expertise is necessary to design and work on these projects. Also, materials and equipment are expensive and require significant infrastructure to store and transport.

Differentiation is minimal, except for large and complex projects, as contractors must abide by specific codes and guidelines set by the government. Advancements in design and other facets are often spread industry-wide.
Capital intensity for bridge and elevated highway contractors is moderate. Projects require contractors to purchase heavy construction equipment, including earthmovers, cranes and asphalt pavers.

basis_points.basis_title: Competition for government contracts rides on price
basis_points.basis_description: The government always gives contracts to the lowest bidder, inducing price-based competition among contractors.
There are plenty of projects to go around. With the government increasing its focus on infrastructure and the backlog of projects piling up, the number of contractors has increased.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Need spread thin across the United States creates a sparse industry
concentration_points.concentration_description: With bridges and elevated highways needing service nationwide, handling projects quickly is key to success. So, contractors operate locally, concentrating all their resources on a small area to quickly get their materials and equipment to projects.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Unstable economic conditions and larger projects have led to consolidation
concentration_points.concentration_description: As the largest contractors can offer the best rates and take on the biggest projects. So, larger contractors are particularly successful in large cities.
With the maintenance backlog and the need for bridges and elevated highways growing, new companies have been encouraged to begin operating and find their place.

concentration_points.concentration_title: As the United States continues to rely heavily on automobiles
concentration_points.concentration_description: Additions and renovations to elevated highways and bridges will only grow in demand and bolster new entrants.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Profit Has Inched Down Amid Slow Growth
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Since contractors primarily receive business through government funding, profit is limited. The government shops around to find the lowest bidder, keeping the average profit margin steady. When tax revenue declines, so does the government's propensity to spend on bridge and elevated highway construction. So, contractors must limit other operational costs to preserve profit.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Slower spending for bridge and elevated highway construction has increased price-based competition among contractors
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Contractors have looked to underbid one another to gain business, sacrificing profit gains.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Wages Have Grown Along With Growth Late
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Bridge and elevated highway construction are more complex than many other construction projects. So, bridge and elevated highway workers command higher wages to work on them. Contractors rely on civil engineers, who often have advanced degrees and earn high salaries, keeping wage costs high.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Contractors have enjoyed growth late as pandemic-related disruptions have eased, inching up wage costs
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Labor shortages hammering the construction sector amid an aging age force have forced contractors to hike wages to attract and retain workers.
Most projects command large amounts of strong materials like cement, steel and asphalt to secure the safety of elevated highways and bridges, keeping purchase costs high.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Balancing purchase costs with labor is key to success
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Lightweight, low-cost materials are the most appealing. This trend has led to the advent of different types of concrete and the increased use of aluminum.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Capital intensity for bridge and elevated highway contractors is moderate. Projects require contractors to purchase heavy construction equipment, including earthmovers, cranes and asphalt pavers.

volatility_points.volatility_description: As the pandemic hit the United States, government funding was needed elsewhere to support struggling individuals and businesses. While this included some funding for contractors, projects were put on hold. Since travel was severely limited, maintenance and repair projects were pushed further down the line, adding to the substantial backlog that will take years to complete, creating consistent demand for contractors.

volatility_points.volatility_title: POPULATION GROWTH WILL NECESSITATE ADDITIONS AND ALTERATIONS
volatility_points.volatility_description: As the general population grows and more US citizens move into cities, traffic will continue to congest. Additions and alterations to elevated highways and bridges will help alleviate this struggle. Substitutes for automobiles are limited in the United States, ensuring that elevated highways and bridges will remain essential for everyday transportation.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: STRIDES ARE BEING MADE TO IMPROVE THE LONGEVITY OF BRIDGES AND ELEVATED HIGHWAYS
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: As the deterioration of old bridges and elevated highways across the country has become apparent, contractors have focused on ways to improve the longevity of these constructions and the repairs made to them. The development of precast modular concrete and fiberglass-reinforced concrete will help contractors achieve these goals, as they are stronger and more resistant to corrosion than their older counterparts.

Contractors are constantly seeking ways to quicken their construction to increase the number of projects they can take on and improve revenue as timeliness is a crucial consideration in winning contracts. Design improvements have sometimes lessened the number of necessary input materials, while alternative, lightweight materials like aluminum bridge decking have reduced repair times.

FAQs.question: Do your sales depend on the overall health of the US economy?
FAQs.answer: Demand for industry services is mostly dependent on the age of infrastructure assets and the need to establish new bridges. Oftentimes, the government will enact countercyclical budgetary action to stimulate demand for industry services during a downturn.

FAQs.question: Does your company service only one market segment or a variety?
FAQs.answer: Diversified operators will likely exhibit lower degrees of revenue volatility, aiding profitability. Nondiversified operators will likely be more subject to output price fluctuations, hindering profitability.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to excess revenue volatility?
FAQs.answer: Industry revenue volatility is mostly a function of public spending levels. Revenue volatility has moderated in recent years with consistent federal spending.

FAQs.question: Is your company located in proximity to key buying and selling markets?
FAQs.answer: Contractors located in proximity to project sites will likely exhibit lower transportation costs and higher profitability. Contractors located in proximity to key building material input suppliers will exhibit lower purchase costs and higher profitability.

FAQs.question: How is your company leveraging the latest technologies?
FAQs.answer: Contractors leveraging the latest technologies will likely exhibit higher operating efficiency and higher profitability. Contractors that do not adopt the latest technologies can become uncompetitive and may be forced to exit the industry.

FAQs.question: Has your company been able to reduce wage costs via automation?
FAQs.answer: By using drones and other site mapping technology, labor resources can be redirected towards more efficient tasks. Wage costs can be further reduced via the subcontracting of nonessential, low-skill employees.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all occupational health and safety requirements are upheld?
FAQs.answer: Compliant operators will likely exhibit lower insurance premiums and costs, boosting profitability. Noncompliant operators will likely be subject to insurance cost increases, undercutting profitability.

FAQs.question: Is your company prepared to adapt to shifting environmental regulations?
FAQs.answer: Contractors with a penchant for environmentally friendly building methods and practices may be favored by the public, boosting sales. Noncompliant operators will likely be subject to fines and penalties, limiting profitability.

FAQs.question: Has your company had any difficulty financing current operations?
FAQs.answer: Funding for projects tends to stem from the public sector, whereby legislation authorizing funds for transportation and highways has been inconsistent. Private companies that do not have the funds to initiate a project may issue debt instruments such as bonds.

FAQs.question: How does your profit margin compare to those of your biggest competitors?
FAQs.answer: Contractors that buy out competitors will likely increase geographic reach and project scope, reducing per unit costs via scale economies, boosting profitability. Contractors that enter into long-term input supply contracts with upstream building materials producers will likely exhibit lower purchase costs.

FAQs.question: How do you attract and retain skilled employees? Are there channels for promotion and career development within your company?
FAQs.answer: Given the high level of subcontracted labor in this industry and the dispersed geographic nature of operations, operators must be able to readily recruit and maintain a flexible and multiskilled workforce.

FAQs.question: How do you make sure your prices are attractive to customers? How effective is your company at competing on tender?
FAQs.answer: In a market driven by price competition, contractors must be capable of securing new project contracts by providing potential clients with attractively low bids, while ensuring adequate profitability and cash flow.

FAQs.question: What is your process for screening for individuals with good communication and interpersonal skills? How do you hone employee negotiation skills?
FAQs.answer: Operators must have the capacity to develop viable infrastructure agreements with private and public-sector clients, local regulatory authorities, labor and material suppliers in a competitive market.

FAQs.question: How will you mitigate the threat of an increasing yield on the 10-year Treasury note? What alternative methods might you take to raise money for industry construction?
FAQs.answer: Interest rates determine how expensive it is for the public and private sectors to raise money for bridge and elevated highway construction.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor the price of cement? What steps do you take to offset increased input costs?
FAQs.answer: Project managers and contractors typically bid for funding and contracts based on estimated costs.

FAQs.question: Do you track government funding for highways? How do government funding trends influence the prevalence of PPOs?
FAQs.answer: The vast majority of industry projects are funded by the public sector.
